addressleaf.section:
To
e right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England

16 Octo
b
1591
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
Newmegen./

page.lettertext:
fol.112r
May it please yo
r
good L. having signified
in my last
e 11 of this moneth, upon what com-
position Nieumeghen would yelde, I am further
to advertise
at
e next day after we came
into
e towne: w
ch
we founde full of ruines
and crased houses, by reason of
e fort, on
e
other side of
e river, w
ch
beatte continually
upon it. But otherwise a faire towne, and
greatly beautified w
t
ancient buildinges of
e
Romaines: as bothe by their stories, and
e viewe
it self of
e places, we might easely conceave.
There is also w
t
in it good stoare of inhabitants,
but poore for
e most, and exceedingly devoted
to
e
Pope
and
e Spaniard. Howbeit w
t
muche
a doe, they have taken an othe to joine w
t
these
Provinces in
e general Union: and have ad-
mitted a garrison of 6 Enseignes, w
ch
is thought
w
t
e Fort of
Cnossenbourgh
sufficiently able to
master
e burghers. They have bin very
well intreated and w
t
speciall favor to all
their demaundes,
at when we entred
e towne,
we found both their shoppes open, and
e people
so muche
buisied
about their daily trafficke, as if no
innovation had hapned unto them. Whiche is
hoped will occasion, and to
at intent it is done,
at others heereafter will surrender
e sooner.
I have sent yo
r
L. heerew
t
a letter from Count
Maurice
to her
Ma
tie
by w
ch
I thinke he doth ad-
vertise
e successe of this enterprise.
It hath bin this morning debated with some ear-
nest contradiction, howe
e forces in feelde should
fol.112v
should be next imploied. To reherse unto yo
r
L.
e diversitie of opinions, would but make
a tedious letter: but
e resolution is taken,
at
the winter is comming on, and many diseased of
the souldiers, they shall presently all retire unto
their garrisons. Moreover there are of
the chiefest of Nieumeghen, w
ch
put us in good
hope, and that upon their knowledge,
at if the
towne of
Venlo
were but summoned by some
fewe of o
r
troupes, they will surrender of them-
selves, w
t
out attending any siege: as being wea-
ry of
e Spaniard, and w
t
out any garrison.
To
e effecting heereof
e said parties doe proffer
their service very willingly, and themselves to
goe in person, w
ch
is nowe in consultation, and
yo
r
L. by my next shall knowe
e
successe.
Of
e Enemies forces we are advertised
that there are at
Grave,
of horse and foote, to-
wardes 1200 and at
Mastricht
2500 whiche is
all that we can learne
at he hath in these quar-
ters. For he sendeth still for
France,
but it is
by times, and by peece meale, w
t
out making
any bruite. But of his going in person, we are
nothing yet certaine.
And so I take my humble
leave. From Nieumeghen. Oc
t
16
1591
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden. Tho. Bodley
